intro: Acalypha chathamensis, commonly known as Chatham Island hibiscus, is a flowering plant native to the Chatham Islands of New Zealand. It belongs to the Euphorbiaceae family and is characterized by its showy, hibiscus-like flowers that are typically pink or red. The plant has palmate leaves with five to seven lobes, and it produces small, capsule-like fruits. It thrives in coastal environments and is adapted to the unique ecological conditions of its habitat. Due to its limited distribution and conservation status, it is considered a rare and endemic species.

Due to its limited range and habitat specificity, it is considered vulnerable to environmental changes and human disturbance. Conservation efforts are ongoing to protect this unique plant from threats such as invasive species and habitat loss.
